column1: Considerations for Market Professionals
I believe that initial coin offerings – whether they represent offerings of securities or not – can be effective ways for entrepreneurs and others to raise funding
column2: including for innovative projects. However
column3: any such activity that involves an offering of securities must be accompanied by the important disclosures
column4: processes and other investor protections that our securities laws require. A change in the structure of a securities offering does not change the fundamental point that when a security is being offered
column5: our securities laws must be followed.[4] Said another way
column6: replacing a traditional corporate interest recorded in a central ledger with an enterprise interest recorded through a blockchain entry on a distributed ledger may change the form of the transaction
column7: but it does not change the substance.

column1: I urge market professionals
column2: including securities lawyers
column3: accountants and consultants
column4: to read closely the investigative report we released earlier this year (the “21(a) Report”)[5] and review our subsequent enforcement actions.[6] In the 21(a) Report
column5: the Commission applied longstanding securities law principles to demonstrate that a particular token constituted an investment contract and therefore was a security under our federal securities laws. Specifically
column6: we concluded that the token offering represented an investment of money in a common enterprise with a reasonable expectation of profits to be derived from the entrepreneurial or managerial efforts of others.

column1: Following the issuance of the 21(a) Report
column2: certain market professionals have attempted to highlight utility characteristics of their proposed initial coin offerings in an effort to claim that their proposed tokens or coins are not securities. Many of these assertions appear to elevate form over substance. Merely calling a token a “utility” token or structuring it to provide some utility does not prevent the token from being a security. Tokens and offerings that incorporate features and marketing efforts that emphasize the potential for profits based on the entrepreneurial or managerial efforts of others continue to contain the hallmarks of a security under U.S. law. On this and other points where the application of expertise and judgment is expected
column3: I believe that gatekeepers and others
column4: including securities lawyers
column5: accountants and consultants
column6: need to focus on their responsibilities. I urge you to be guided by the principal motivation for our registration
column7: offering process and disclosure requirements: investor protection and
column8: in particular
column9: the protection of our Main Street investors.

column1: I also caution market participants against promoting or touting the offer and sale of coins without first determining whether the securities laws apply to those actions. Selling securities generally requires a license
column2: and experience shows that excessive touting in thinly traded and volatile markets can be an indicator of “scalping
column3: ” “pump and dump” and other manipulations and frauds. Similarly
column4: I also caution those who operate systems and platforms that effect or facilitate transactions in these products that they may be operating unregistered exchanges or broker-dealers that are in violation of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

column1: On cryptocurrencies
column2: I want to emphasize two points. First
column3: while there are cryptocurrencies that do not appear to be securities
column4: simply calling something a “currency” or a currency-based product does not mean that it is not a security. Before launching a cryptocurrency or a product with its value tied to one or more cryptocurrencies
column5: its promoters must either (1) be able to demonstrate that the currency or product is not a security or (2) comply with applicable registration and other requirements under our securities laws. Second
column6: brokers
column7: dealers and other market participants that allow for payments in cryptocurrencies
column8: allow customers to purchase cryptocurrencies on margin
column9: or otherwise use cryptocurrencies to facilitate securities transactions should exercise particular caution
column10: including ensuring that their cryptocurrency activities are not undermining their anti-money laundering and know-your-customer obligations.[7] As I have stated previously
column11: these market participants should treat payments and other transactions made in cryptocurrency as if cash were being handed from one party to the other.

column1: Additional Discussion of Cryptocurrencies
column2: ICOs and Securities Regulation

column1: Cryptocurrencies. Speaking broadly
column2: cryptocurrencies purport to be items of inherent value (similar
column3: for instance
column4: to cash or gold) that are designed to enable purchases
column5: sales and other financial transactions. They are intended to provide many of the same functions as long-established currencies such as the U.S. dollar
column6: euro or Japanese yen but do not have the backing of a government or other body. Although the design and maintenance of cryptocurrencies differ
column7: proponents of cryptocurrencies highlight various potential benefits and features of them
column8: including (1) the ability to make transfers without an intermediary and without geographic limitation
column10: (3) lower transaction costs compared to other forms of payment and (4) the ability to publicly verify transactions. Other often-touted features of cryptocurrencies include personal anonymity and the absence of government regulation or oversight. Critics of cryptocurrencies note that these features may facilitate illicit trading and financial transactions
column11: and that some of the purported beneficial features may not prove to be available in practice.

column1: It has been asserted that cryptocurrencies are not securities and that the offer and sale of cryptocurrencies are beyond the SEC’s jurisdiction. Whether that assertion proves correct with respect to any digital asset that is labeled as a cryptocurrency will depend on the characteristics and use of that particular asset. In any event
column2: it is clear that
column3: just as the SEC has a sharp focus on how U.S. dollar
column4: euro and Japanese yen transactions affect our securities markets
column5: we have the same interests and responsibilities with respect to cryptocurrencies. This extends
column6: for example
column7: to securities firms and other market participants that allow payments to be made in cryptocurrencies
column8: set up structures to invest in or hold cryptocurrencies
column9: or extend credit to customers to purchase or hold cryptocurrencies.

column1: Initial Coin Offerings. Coinciding with the substantial growth in cryptocurrencies
column2: companies and individuals increasingly have been using initial coin offerings to raise capital for their businesses and projects. Typically these offerings involve the opportunity for individual investors to exchange currency such as U.S. dollars or cryptocurrencies in return for a digital asset labeled as a coin or token.

column1: These offerings can take many different forms
column2: and the rights and interests a coin is purported to provide the holder can vary widely. A key question for all ICO market participants: “Is the coin or token a security?” As securities law practitioners know well
column3: the answer depends on the facts. For example
column4: a token that represents a participation interest in a book-of-the-month club may not implicate our securities laws
column5: and may well be an efficient way for the club’s operators to fund the future acquisition of books and facilitate the distribution of those books to token holders. In contrast
column6: many token offerings appear to have gone beyond this construct and are more analogous to interests in a yet-to-be-built publishing house with the authors
column7: books and distribution networks all to come. It is especially troubling when the promoters of these offerings emphasize the secondary market trading potential of these tokens. Prospective purchasers are being sold on the potential for tokens to increase in value – with the ability to lock in those increases by reselling the tokens on a secondary market – or to otherwise profit from the tokens based on the efforts of others. These are key hallmarks of a security and a securities offering.

column1: By and large
column2: the structures of initial coin offerings that I have seen promoted involve the offer and sale of securities and directly implicate the securities registration requirements and other investor protection provisions of our federal securities laws. Generally speaking
column3: these laws provide that investors deserve to know what they are investing in and the relevant risks involved.

column1: I have asked the SEC’s Division of Enforcement to continue to police this area vigorously and recommend enforcement actions against those that conduct initial coin offerings in violation of the federal securities laws.
Conclusion
We at the SEC are committed to promoting capital formation. The technology on which cryptocurrencies and ICOs are based may prove to be disruptive
column2: transformative and efficiency enhancing. I am confident that developments in fintech will help facilitate capital formation and provide promising investment opportunities for institutional and Main Street investors alike.

column1: I encourage Main Street investors to be open to these opportunities
column2: but to ask good questions
column3: demand clear answers and apply good common sense when doing so. When advising clients
column4: designing products and engaging in transactions

column6: regulations and guidance
column7: as well as our principles-based securities law framework
column8: which has served us well in the face of new developments for more than 80 years. Staff providing assistance on these matters remain available at FinTech@sec.gov.

column1: Why Monero

column1: Many cryptocurrency users falsely believe that because their logged data is stored in an encrypted fashion on a digital ledger that it can't be traced back to them -- but this just isn't true. In fact
column2: the Internal Revenue Service recently won a legal battle against Coinbase that required the cryptocurrency exchange to turn over information on 14

Bitcoin futures and swaps are subject to the jurisdiction of the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (""CFTC""). Although bitcoin and other crypto-currencies are a novel class of commodities
column2: derivatives based on these products are regulated under the Commodity Exchange Act and rules of the CFTC and National Futures Association (""NFA"") just like all other derivative contracts. This has numerous immediate and practical implications for market participants: • Futures commission merchants – Any entity that solicits or accepts orders to buy or sell bitcoin futures or swaps and accepts money or assets from customers for such orders must register with the CFTC as a futures commission merchant. • Introducing brokers – Any entity that solicits or accepts orders for bitcoin futures or swaps but does not accept customer funds must register as an introducing broker. • Commodity trading advisors – Any entity that
column3: for compensation or profit
column4: advises others
column5: directly or indirectly
column6: as to the value of or the advisability of trading bitcoin futures or swaps must register as a commodity trading advisor. • Commodity pool operators – Any fund or collective investment vehicle that trades bitcoin futures or swaps is a commodity pool
column7: the operator of which must register as a commodity pool operator. • Swap dealers – Any entity that holds itself out as a dealer in bitcoin swaps; makes a market in bitcoin swaps; regularly enters into bitcoin swaps with counterparties as an ordinary course of business for its own account; or engages in more than a de minimis volume of bitcoin swaps as a dealer must register as a swap dealer. Exemptions from some or all of the regulatory requirements associated with each of these registration categories may be available depending on the specific facts and circumstances of each individual or firm.

column1: Devil in the Details: Reference Price Calculations

Each bitcoin derivative contract attempts to accurately represent prices in the physical bitcoin market through the methodology defined in the contract specifications for calculating the reference price for its bitcoin contract. This calculation is the core commercial term of the contract because it determines whether the derivative will function as an effective and reliable proxy for a position in the physical market. However
column2: this calculation also provides would-be market manipulators with instructions on how the reference price the futures and swaps contracts will be determined and
column3: in theory
column4: how those prices could be manipulated for their individual gain. Market participants should use particular care when trading in both bitcoin futures or swaps and related markets because this type of trading activity may give rise to heightened regulatory scrutiny.
